elements.title: Protection Model Progressive Reveal — Build Trust Through Staged Disclosure
elements.problem: Theodore's biggest anxiety was committing without seeing the space (04:07). The agent resolved it with a 3-step explanation: (1) sign lease, (2) 24-hour inspection, (3) full refund if unsatisfied. But this protection model is buried in terms or absent from the listing page entirely. Greever's 'set the context' principle (Ch 3) says the most important information must be presented before asking for commitment.
elements.solution: Reveal the protection model progressively across phases: On listing pages, show a compact 'Protection Shield' with icons for each safeguard. On proposal confirmation, expand to show the full 3-step process. On acceptance, show a timeline of what happens next. The information architecture follows Greever's 'optimize for memory' — each phase reinforces the same 3 protections with increasing detail. Never make the guest feel unprotected at a decision point.

evidence.quote: You have no obligation for anything until you sign the lease. We hold the payment until you spend at least 24 hours.
evidence.insight: The 3-step protection model is the single most persuasive argument in the guest journey. It must be architecturally prominent.

evidence.quote: Set the Context... Optimize for Memory.
evidence.insight: Greever says critical information must be repeated in different contexts to stick. The protection model needs to appear on listings, proposals, and acceptance — each time with slightly more detail.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Protection guarantees are PRIMARY on any page that asks for financial commitment. Pricing is SECONDARY. Terms/details are TERTIARY.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Phase 1 (listing): Icon strip with 3 shields — '24h guarantee | Money held by SplitLease | Full refund option'. Phase 2 (proposal): Expandable card with each step explained in one sentence. Phase 3 (acceptance): Full timeline showing what happens from signing through 24-hour inspection.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Max 3 protection points at any given phase. No more than 15 words per point. Use icons to reduce reading load.
exclude: Legal terms and conditions at the listing level
Detailed cancellation policy language until acceptance phase

elements.title: Bid/Proposal Purpose Articulation — Show What Submitting Actually Does
elements.problem: Theodore asked 'What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher?' (07:35-07:47). He thought it was an auction. The proposal submission flow provides no articulation of what the submission does, what happens next, or what the guest should expect. This is severity-CRITICAL per Greever's framework: the guest takes the most important action in the journey without understanding it.
elements.solution: Redesign the proposal submission confirmation to answer Greever's Big Three: (1) What problem does it solve? 'Your proposal tells hosts you're interested and at what price — they can accept, counter, or pass.' (2) How does it affect you? 'You'll hear back within 5-7 days. No obligation until you both agree.' (3) Why is it better? 'Unlike bidding wars, we match you 1:1 with compatible hosts.' Show a visual pipeline: Submitted → Agent Review → Host Introduction → Your Decision.

evidence.quote: What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher?
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model (auction) is completely wrong. The UI must replace this mental model proactively.

evidence.quote: What problem does it solve? How does it affect the user? Why is it better than the alternative?
evidence.insight: Greever's Big Three questions are the exact framework for articulating what a proposal submission does.

elements.hierarchy_principle: What happens next is PRIMARY. What you submitted is SECONDARY. Terms/edit options are TERTIARY.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediately after submission: animated pipeline showing 4 steps. Current step highlighted. Expected timeline for each step. Agent name and photo if assigned.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Max 4 pipeline steps visible. Each step: icon + 4-word label + estimated time.
exclude: Other guests who bid on the same listing
Host's decision criteria or competing bids

elements.title: Platform Identity Declaration — Differentiate From Short-Term Rentals in 5 Seconds
elements.problem: Theodore simultaneously submitted to SplitLease and Airbnb (00:11), indicating zero comprehension of the difference. The agent spent 2 minutes explaining the core differentiator: no short-term occupancy taxes, minimum 6 weeks, split scheduling (06:22-06:53). This is severity-CRITICAL for discovery: if the guest doesn't understand what SplitLease IS, every subsequent design decision fails. Greever's 'everyone is a designer' chapter argues that the FIRST thing a stakeholder needs is context — what are we even talking about?
elements.solution: On every discovery-phase surface (homepage, landing pages, search results header), show a 3-column comparison: 'Airbnb = Nightly stays, expensive, short-term | Traditional Lease = 12 months, locked in, no flexibility | SplitLease = 6+ weeks, your days only, 40-60% less than Airbnb.' Use icons and bold numbers, not paragraphs. The comparison must take 5 seconds to scan and answer: 'Why would I use this instead of what I already know?'

evidence.quote: I also submitted an Airbnb request.
evidence.insight: The guest sees SplitLease and Airbnb as interchangeable. The UI's first job is to break this equivalence.

evidence.quote: Set the Context... The most important thing you could ask is 'What are we trying to communicate?'
evidence.insight: The VP's question to Greever applies to SplitLease's homepage: before showing features, communicate WHAT you are and WHY you exist.

elements.hierarchy_principle: 'What is SplitLease' is PRIMARY on any discovery surface. Listings/search are SECONDARY. Company info is TERTIARY.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Landing page hero: 3-column comparison (5 seconds). Below fold: single-sentence explainer with video. Search header: persistent reminder 'Mid-term stays, your days only.'
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Max 3 comparison columns. Max 6 words per cell. One number per column (price, duration, flexibility metric).
exclude: Company history/founding story on discovery pages
Detailed feature lists before the guest understands the concept

elements.title: Weekly Savings Dashboard — Articulate the Discount Value Continuously
elements.problem: Theodore signed up for the 40% discount tier (12:07), but once in the active lease, the UI provides no ongoing articulation of what this discount is worth in concrete terms. Greever says 'being articulate means success' — the discount must be articulated weekly, not just at signup. Without continuous value visibility, the cleaning/flexibility obligation feels like unpaid labor rather than a smart deal.
elements.solution: On the guest Stays Manager, show a persistent 'Your Savings' module: weekly savings, cumulative savings, and comparison to Airbnb equivalent. After each cleaning photo submission, animate the savings counter increasing. After each schedule flex accommodation, show 'Your flexibility saved $X this week.' The information hierarchy: savings total (PRIMARY) → this week's breakdown (SECONDARY) → Airbnb comparison (TERTIARY).

evidence.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
evidence.insight: The 40% figure is the anchor — but it means nothing without a dollar amount. $X saved this week is concrete; 40% is abstract.

evidence.quote: Business... Design... Research... Choose a Message.
evidence.insight: Greever says choose ONE message per communication. For the savings dashboard, the message is: 'Your effort is paying off — here's the proof.'

elements.hierarchy_principle: Cumulative savings total is PRIMARY (big number, bold). This week's savings is SECONDARY. Airbnb comparison is TERTIARY (smaller, contextual).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Default view: savings total + this week. Expand: per-week breakdown. Tap: comparison to Airbnb equivalent pricing.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: One big number (cumulative savings). Two supporting data points (this week, vs. Airbnb). No more.
scan_order: Cumulative savings total ($X saved so far)
exclude: Cleaning compliance percentage as a standalone metric
Historical graphs or charts that require interpretation
